item.description: Road Kill Truckers puts the players behind the wheel of a truck that is barreling down a rural highway. Normally, the local wildlife crosses the road without any problems, but not today. Players roll custom animal dice to determine which animals are in the lanes ahead, then decide which lane to swerve into, rolling dice to see if they hit or miss the animal in the new lane. Each round has the players in a different turn order and each players' choice can affect the other players by removing available options. The animals are assigned a point value from 1 to 6 and the players roll six sided dice to see if they can roll a number equal to or greater than the animal's value. The winner is determined once the trucks reach the end of the road by adding up all the points from the animals that were successfully hit.

In Roman antiquity this game was known as Alea, meaning 'gambling', but came to be called tabula, 'board' or 'table', since it was played on a board. Tabula is the gambling game of which the Emperor Claudius was most fond. Around the year 50, Claudius wrote a history of the game of Tabula which, unfortunately, has not survived. His imperial carriage was equipped with an alveus, a Tabula playing board, so that he could play while travelling. Tabula is also the game which was primarily responsible for the gambling mania which swept Rome prior to its being declared illegal under the Republic. The fine for gambling at any other time except the Saturnalia was four times the stakes, although this law was only weakly and sporadically enforced.

Setup: The equipment for Tabula is the same as in backgammon except that each player has three dice instead of two. 
All checkers start off the board. Both players enter their fifteen checkers into the same starting table and move them around the board in the same direction.

Object: The object of the game is to move all of your checkers to the finishing table and then bear them off. The first player to bear off all his checkers wins the game.

Welcome to SuperMegaCon, the convention board game. The game for SCIFI, GAMING, HORROR, and COMICS convention fans. This is the weekend of 24-hour fandemonium you’ve been waiting for all year!

The goal of this convention is to be the Attendee that has the most fun by collecting more Swag and attending more Events than all the other Attendees. Don’t let the lack of Food, Sleep, or Bathroom Breaks slow you down.

During SuperMegaCan you can grab Swag and attend Events, visit our lovely Gift Shop, run to FastGoQuikMart for Snacks and Drinks, rest at one of our convenient area Hotels, eat at fine area Restaurants and our own Snax Bar, catch the Auction where you can get tons of Swag or extra Cash, visit our Registration booth to sell your own Swag to other Attendees, enjoy Special Events in our spacious Auditorium, Volunteer for extra cash, and Much, Much, More!! So get SuperMegaCon and Play the Convention!!!

From website:

Agent Saboteur is a face-paced card game full of bluffing and sabotage, where you command a team of international spies trying to stop the terrorists and build your reputation in the process. One of the great things about this game is that no one sits on the sidelines and waits for the other players to get done. For the casual gamer, Agent Saboteur is easy to teach, fun to play, and will quickly become the game you play most often. For the hobby gamer, it will become the go-to game you get out when friends or family stop by.

The Story: “Welcome, handler XXXXXXXXXX. Your reputation precedes you. That little matter you took care of in XXXXXX was quite impressive. Some believe you may be ready, so from here on your organization will only be tasked with stopping the type of incidents that end up on the front page. The last agents that got sent got themselves XXXXXX within a week and we’re still explaining the glow in XXXXXXXXXXX. Everything you hear, see, or do from this point forward is strictly classified. Good luck. You’ll need it.“

The Gameplay: Your assignment is to use the spies and mission updates in your hand to stop the terrorists. Whichever player gathers the most points in incidents wins. To do so you'll work the source to gain more agents to your team, but if you push your luck, you may get made and lose them all. Then you'll need to send your agents on missions, traveling incognito using your fake passports. Beware, if the other agents guess where you're sending them, they can sabotage the attempt. Keep your cards close to your chest and you just might live.

name.value: Mug Book: The Game of Street Crimes

item.description:
After establishing their rank, based on the running score accumulated during previous games, The players read the Crime Report which is the scenario for the players to solve. Using the supplies given, the players race to solve the crime and make an arrest. Points are scored or lost depending on performance.The object is to win enough games to move up through the ranks to become Deputy Police Chief.

The game is packaged in a thick plastic pouch and contains:
- Rules
- Mug Book of Criminals
- Crime Scenario Book #1
- Directory
- Time Sequence Chart
- Map of the City

The game seems to have been, shall we say, inspired by Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective by Sleuth.

Engage you are the commander of all ground forces (Infantry and Armor units) on one of the many battle fields of WWII; North Africa, Italy, France, Germany, Russia or one of the many islands in the Pacific. With its simple gaming mechanic to move and fire your military units everyone can play. It has a unique combat system that puts you in complete control of your game and just enough complexity for the hard-core war gamer. Each player will secretly acquire and deploy their military units and manage their skill level. Players’ will move and fire their military units, simulating simultaneous engagement. Victory is achieved by capturing and holding the fortified bunkers in the middle of the open battlefield. You will need to outwit your opponent and stop their advancement. All command decisions are made by ‘you’ in determining your outcome; luck is not a factor! There is no luck of the dice or the need to draw the correct cards to achieve victory. If you lose, then it was your decisions and your strategy that failed! No game will ever play the same as your decisions will alter the direction of each game.

Engage has a large playing board 35"x21" and includes 96 detailed British & Italian military units (64 infantry units and 32 armor units)

Engage is designed for 2 players and can expand to 3 or 4 players (team play).

Engage has 4 expansion modules to expand your play options. American units, German units, Japanese units & Russian units for a total of 192 additions pieces.

item.description:
From the rulebook:
"The game consists of a pack of 56 cards, each bearing a LETTER and about 150 discs with which to purchase the letters.
The OBJECT of each player is to make a word of FOUR LETTERS from the cards which he buys at auction in competition with the other players. The first player completing a WORD OF FOUR LETTERS wins the game."

The barnyard is getting crowded and the animals are getting bored. So what do you do to fill an afternoon? Why not battle it out for bragging rights and first go at the trough tonight?

Barnyard Brawl is a two player abstract strategy game in the spirit of Chinese Chess. Players control armies of farm animals across the barnyard.

Each animal has its own movement rules and some come with special abilities. Animals may defeat opponents of equal or lesser value, or two lesser pieces may sandwich a higher value piece to take it out.

Players also begin the game with two randomly drawn Combat Cards which allow them to break the rules at some point in the game.

To add to the mix there are fences and a mud-hole that may be set up in different patterns to change the barnyard.

Finally a game of Pool that fits in your pocket and won’t damage your rec room walls … If you play it right …

Behind the 8 Ball is a simulation of Pool played with a standard deck of Cards. Players make shots by pairing up two cards from their hand (by adding or subtracting) to come up with a value matching one of the Pool Balls.

The value of the shots that miss (don't match a ball still on the table) are carried over to the opponent and must be added to their next shot.Thus it is possible, even in missing to put your opponent in a bad position.

There are also rules for making trick shots, scratches, and incorporating rebounds into your shots.

Download this pnp football (soccer) management game and prepare to take your team to glory (or failure).

Starting in the lowly fourth division, sign new players, train up those you have, sell the dead weight, increase the size of your stadium, get new sponsors, hire and fire staff and cry as injury strikes your squad at the worst possible moment.

Finally pick your team, your formation and take on 31 other unique teams with their own strengths and weaknesses. Win and the world is yours. Lose and glory starts to look a long way away.

Footy Manager can be played solo or multiplayer with friends. All you need are the files, rules, a pencil, eraser and a couple of six sided dice! Unique mechanisms make every play-through different as players retire, start or stop improving, get injured, request transfers and more.

If you've got a long trip, a quiet evening in or some time to kill on a commute then just print off the sheets and get playing!

item.description:
A Fun Twist of the Classic game.
Players in this quick-playing word game compete to win the pot! Be the first to play a double letter word or seven-letter word and win the pot. Players compete for 12 pots total per round. No worries if play gets hectic, the letter tiles securely lock into the molded grid. And scoring is easy, the player with the most chips after three rounds wins!

For 2 - 4 players, ages 10 and up. Contents Include: 100 molded letter tiles, molded tile grid, perimeter chip board and instructions.

Players have to throw small rings, made of rubber, trying to land them on a board with hooks on it. You score points depending which hook it lands on (indeed, if it lands on one).
The board is illustrated with Noddy in the centre and Big Ears to the left and Policeman Plod to the right.

link.value: Eelco Martinus ten Harmsen van der Beek

item.description:
Card game featuring characters from the Pooh stories by A. A. Milne.
A variation of the traditional playing card game called Beggar My Neighbour in Britain.
Players turn over a card from their stack. If it is a card without a number, the next player has a turn. If one of the numbered cards is drawn (they feature Christopher Robin, Kanga and Roo, Piglet and Winnie the Pooh) then the next player has to add cards to the central stack, how many cards being decided by the number on the previous card. If a player runs out of cards, he or her is out of the game. 'Last Man Standing' wins.

LEGO Champion is a racing game in which you build the track as you race for the finish line. Each time you add to the track you have to initiate a challenge, and the winner of the challenge jumps ahead. The basic game includes five challenges, with an extra optional challenge in the rules booklet and additional challenges scheduled for release online. These challenges are:


 On Target: Everyone throws a brick and tries to get closest to the target.
 Bluffing Bricks: Everyone hides three bricks, then takes turns guessing the total number of one colour.
 Topple Tower: Everyone takes turns adding bricks to a tower without making it fall.
 Codebreaker: The challenger builds a secret code and everyone takes turns to work it out.
 Speedbuilder: The challenger builds a multi-couloured shape and everyone races to match it.
 Bowled Over: Everyone takes turns to knock down bowling pins with the LEGO Dice.


There is rules for two special dice sides in the ruleset:


 Take Your Pick: If you roll ‘Question mark’, choose any challenge to play.
 Double Cross: If you roll ‘Jolly Roger’, swap places on the track with any other player and then play the challenge that matches the brick you are now standing on.


You can find rules for extra challenges on http://www.lego.com/legogames/en-us/Downloads/Default.aspx
The extra challenges are:


 Bridge Collapse: Everyone take turns to add a brick to a bridge, and then lift it without letting it collapse.
 Memory Master: The Challenger hides a brick taken from a pile and everyone tries to name the colour of the hidden brick.
 Blind Builder: The Challenger builds a shape and everyone races to build a matching shape behind their backs.
 More Bluffing Bricks: Everyone hides four bricks and then takes turns to guess the total number of one colour.
 Push Your Luck: Everyone takes turns to collect the most differently coloured bricks.

item.description:
Alcatraz: The Scapegoat is a game about conflicted loyalties. On one hand, the players work together to bust out of the famous prison; on the other hand they all know that one of them will be left behind as the scapegoat.

Alcatraz is a peculiar game because while it is cooperative in some aspects, with players needing to work together to complete tasks, the game has loads of negative interaction as one player will always be the scapegoat. You don't want to be that guy. You don't "go all in," you don't always keep your promises, and you don't do "what's best for the group." Instead, you do everything you can to become indispensable, and "everything" is literal here – even if it means stealing from, betraying, and blackmailing other players.

In order to escape from Alcatraz, the players need to complete six parts of a plan. Each part is a "pick-up and deliver" task requiring specific items obtained in different parts of the prison. Once each part of the plan is completed, every player but the scapegoat moves a little closer to escaping, with the scapegoat being voted on each round by all the players – most likely the player who contributed the least to completing that particular task, but you never know. Thus, you could say that Alcatraz is a cooperative game – but with a twist.

The map of the prison constituting the play area is generated randomly each game, providing high replayability. Alcatraz is designed for 3-4 players, and due to its theme and complex gameplay is best suited for mature players.

item.description:
A game released because of the Disney cartoon.
44 cards in four sets of eleven cards. Players have to form runs or sets (as in Rummy). The game ends when six hands have been played or at the end of any hand when a score of 100 or more is achieved.
The cards are illustrated with characters and scenes from the film.

De Helden van onze Planeet is a card game in which players try to reach the number 2020 first, because 2020 is the year that WWF has set as goal to live in harmony with nature.

Players start in the year 0 and try to be the first to reach the year 2020 by playing out cards with numbers. These numbers represent years and players have to reach year 2020 exactly! There are of course special cards to block another player, steal years from another player, or play extra cards. The cards itself have photos and information on them about nature, wildlife, and preservation of the environment. So besides the game-play there is a learning factor for children.

A children's card game, rather like Memory, where you have to win pairs of cards. Complete luck at first but as more cards are revealed (and then placed back face-down), memory comes into the game. An easier version for very young children is also provided. The company also suggest that Snap could be played with the same cards.
44 cards, illustrated with characters from the Rupert comic strip and the Rupert Annuals that appeared every year.

Card game using characters from a popular cartoon strip in the Daily Mirror newspaper. Players have to play to tricks in the usual way but only Old Boot (the dog in the strip) cards are important because they will earn you points and that is a bad thing, because the player with the lowest total, wins.

Very cheap game, transferring a Battleships' type game to land rather than sea. Sold in packets of charts and rules, no box. Very rare to find. Probably from the Second World War period, when every boy wanted to be a General

A football board game from this mainly card game publisher. The board is made up of 13 squares the length of the pitch, and 7 squares wide. Players move their lead footballers around the pitch. Sadly, I don't have the rules, so I don't know how they are moved but it is probably by dice roll (given the age of the game). The box does say "The NEW Soccer Game of SKILL".

The board is made up of 144 squares, each with either a number (the runs scored with that delivery) or a way of getting out. Each set of six squares is labelled with an over. You start in the first over and end with the 24th over. Players throw a die and move along the row labelled with the first over and check the result. Now the marker is moved back to the start of that over and a die is thrown again, and so on for six deliveries. Then it is the 2nd over, and so on. The publisher thought that it would be a good idea to say it was a game for more than the obvious two players. So three can play (two pair up against the other single player), or four (both teams consist of a pair of players) or five players (two teams of two players and the fifth player just acts as scorer and he gets to shout "Over" at the end of each six deliveries.

From the World of Warcraft TCG site:

Experience raiding content through the World of Warcraft Trading Card Game. Play the role of a hero as your storm Icecrown Citadel with your friends against the evil that has plagued Northrend for too long. Or, play as that evil and conquer the world!

This four-player game has everything you and three friends need to play all in the box. Play as Highlord Tirion Fordring, Lady Jaina Proudmoore, or Queen Sylvanas Windrunner and battle against the Lich King! Each player takes a deck, and the three heroes of Azeroth team-up to free the land from the threats of Icecrown Citadel. If the 3-on-1 seems unfair, know that the Lich King raid deck has some of the most powerful cards you've ever seen. He's no mere mortal! Plus, each deck comes with the hero's legendary weapon: the Ashbringer, Staff of Antonidas, Frostmourne, and Deathwhisper. The decks also feature new art for Fire Blast, Frostbolt, Counterspell, Multi-Shot, Redemption, Hammer of Justice, and others!

Cryptozoic has streamlined the raid deck experience, making it far more friendly to new players. There are no new rules to learn; each player takes his or her turn just as they would in a normal game of World of Warcraft TCG. The included rulebook ensures that even completely green recruits can jump in the action.

The three raiding decks easily convert into tournament-legal Core decks as well. Just replace the hero card, remove the legendary weapon, and you can battle at your local Core Constructed or Battlegrounds event.

Each four-player game comes packaged with an Assault on Icecrown Citadel Treasure Pack, and the Treasure Packs are sold separately as well. There are 20 uncommons, 7 rares, and 3 epics in the set. Each pack contains 9 foil cards (8 uncommons and 1 rare or 1 epic) unleashing never-seen-before allies, abilities, quests, and equipment cards into the World of Warcraft TCG card pool. Find Muradin Bronzebeard, High Overlord Saurfang, and Highlord Tirion Fordring as new allies to join your party. Recruit the best of Northrend before you go back to the mainland. You also have the chance to open Loot cards from Worldbreaker: Mottled Drake, Grim Campfire, and Landro's Lil XT.

A 1948 board game by the card game specialists, Pepys.
One player is the Spider and the other players are Flies. Inspired by Ludo, Flies have to get 'home' whilst the Spider must capture 5 Flies before any one Fly player gets all his Flies safely home.

item.description: Players build the tower. The object of the game us to be the only player who doesn't make the tower tumble down.

Players are agents working for a counter terrorist organization. They work with the other players to prevent disasters in the city. They know where the terrorist targets are and must get themselves and other agents to those sites to diffuse the threat. One player is a double agent working with the terrorists. The other players must find a way to make the city safe in order to win.
Cards are played on buildings in the city where threats are taking place. On their turns the players choose one action from 9 available to diffuse the threats. If all threats in the city are eliminated, the players win, but if there are three disasters, the double agent and the terrorists win. A threat becomes a disaster if threat card is drawn that is identical to a threat already in place. Players can deploy other players to danger zones, they can move themselves, follow a tip, gather intelligence, or interrogate suspects. They can confront and kill other agents if they suspect them to be the double agent.

Wildebeest Chess is a large chess variant.

The chess variant attempts to bring balance between leapers and riders in the game.

The game is played on a board of ten rows and eleven columns. Each player has eleven pawns, two rooks, two knights, two bishops, two camels, one queen, one wildebeest, and one king.

A camel has an extended knight jump: it goes one square in one direction and three in the other. Camels may jump (like knights) over occupied squares.

A wildebeest has the combined moves of a camel and knight.

A simulation of re-racing the 108th Kentucky Derby. Cards for all 32 horses that were eligible are included. Unusually, this seems to have been published before the real race was run, so the designer suggests that you could run the race more accurately after the horses are entered in real life.

Movement is by rolling dice and then looking at a chart on the back of each horse's card. On the back of the card, each horse has a set of target numbers for each quarter of the track. Dice are rolled and if you roll one of those numbers, the horse advances. If you don't, the horse doesn't move. Eight(8) horses are in each race, the players divide up the 8 horses.

As 32 horses are provided and only 8 run, you can play a series of 4 races, to use every horse once.

6 games (3 outdoor games and 3 indoor games) that get kids off the couch and running while learning fractions.

Outdoor Games:
- Whole Lot: Learners race to join hands in order to become wholes.
- Order Order: Teams race to put fractions in order from lowest to highest.
- Line Up - Move-Up: Learners setp forward if a fractions is higher and step back if it is lower.

Indoor Games:
- Fraction Attack: Highest fraction card takes all.
- Trade Away: Trade cards with other poayers and become the first to make a whole..
- Fraction Solitaire: Beat the clock to make as many wholes as you can before time runs out.

Components:

 100 fraction cards (Including Half's, Thirds, Fourths, Sixths, and Eighths)
 15 Cips
 1 Timer

What child hasn't dreamed about being Santa Claus? Now they can with Santa Claus the Game! Open the Game box and immediately be transported into the Fantasy, excitement, and joy of Christmas.

In this delightful game players choose a sleigh and start at the North Pole. They race around Santa's Workshop trying to load their sleigh with 5 toys. Once a Santa has 5 toys, they fly off to the town to deliver the toys. Along the way, Santas encounter fun activities like belting out their best "HO HO HO" or Singing their favorite Christmas carol. The first Santa to deliver all their toys wins the game.

A Snooker-based game that needed to be 'made' by any interested gamer. It was self-published in a fanzine from the mid-eighties.

Cards provide a variety of options open to a Snooker player when he comes to the table. When a player takes on a pot, cards are used to generate three decisions. The first card drawn will tell if the shot is Easy, Medium or Hard. The next card will give you the first digit of a two-digit number between 01 and 99. And the third card completes the number. Numerous charts and tables are required for the game.

The rules allow for special events - a Foul Shot, a snooker, Bad Kicks, Getting out of a snooker and a choice of playing safely or riskily.

What's the number one problem facing gamers? Cheeto dust. What's the number two problem? Games that end in ties. After a grueling hour of gaming, you discover that you've tied for first place with your arch nemesis, Toady Johansen. Again. You grab for the rulebook, but Toady is faster than you, and begins reading, "In case of a tie, all players rejoice in their shared victory." You're outraged. Even Toady, who would be languishing in second-to-last place if it weren't for the kingmaking efforts of your other arch nemesis, Art Smithers, is visibly shaken. What is this, the World Cup? Unbelievable.

But now, however, there's a solution to this problem (the tied player one, not that Cheeto issue..that'll have to wait until there are significant technological advances): TieBreaker. TieBreaker is the definitive method for determining who wins a tied game. And even though it's the follow-up from the designer of the award-winning Start Player, TieBreaker isn't at all random; it challenges each tied player to show, once and for all, that he is indeed deserving of victory by having the tied players compete in a simple challenge.

With more than 50 cards and a giant orange TieBreaker meeple, you can always be confident that tied games will be resolved satisfactorily. There will be a winner, and most likely that winner will be you.

Because, regardless of what your so-called politically-correct friends say, it really isn't about how you play the game. It's about crushing Toady Johansen until he cries for his momma.

TieBreaker will debut October 2011 at Spiel.

TieBreaker has already been awarded the Board 2 Pieces Game of the Year for 2011!

item.description:
"An exciting game of skill and chance with all the thrill of Stock Exchange speculation", from the box lid.

The board looks interesting at first glance but prepare for disappointment. Players move round the track on the edge of the board (using the die) and they have a choice when they land on certain squares, to buy or sell stock. Chance cards here are called Ticker or Private Line cards. After an hour or so of play, the Markets close and players' stock are converted into cash. The winner is the player with the most money.

The game was produced in both a large box version and a small box version (but both had the same rules and components).

A word game with 160 letter tiles, 4 racks and 4 playing boards. Each player uses a hand of 8 letters, replenishing them at the end of his turn. In your turn, you hope to make a word from your collection of letters, the longer the better. However, some thought is needed because once a word is played, it can be added to, to make a longer word. Thus you would score some points for the first word, and yet more for the longer second word. So it pays to be thinking this through. The score increases as words get longer (1 for a two letter word, 2 for three, 4 for four, 6 for five, 10 for six, and so on.
They obviously had AP in the 50's because the rules say "To save time, players should be considering their next play while their opponents are playing".
A more advanced game "For experts" allows you to intrduce a little more interaction.

"A Game of Adventure on the High Seas". The box is nice, shaped like a treasure chest, and the map comes rolled up with a ribbon round it.
The board is map of the sea between Sail Point Bay and Treasure Bay, superimposed with squares. The game uses dice but in a novel way. Turn order is decided by chance and that order of play continues for the whole game. We will call the first player 'the Leader'. He throws a red die and consults the compass at the top of the board. There are 6 compass points and each points in a different direction. The number rolled dictates the direction of movement, for all players, this round. Then the Leader throws a black die and moves his ship that many spaces in the correct direction. Each player after that does the same, throw the black die and move, but not the red die as that is only thrown at the start of the round. There is a little choice in movement. You can decide to 'tack' and move in the direct opposite direction of the compass throw, but you don't move so far, in fact, you might not move at all.
There are perils to be avoided, like rocks or the dreaded Seaweed Sea where you just float randomly until clear of it.
The first player to sail into Treasure Bay wins.

A word game that has elements of Reversi in that you turn over letters to your colour when you form a word.
2 player or a 4 player (partnership) game. Each player uses an identical set of 50 tiles, one marked with red, the other blue.
The first player lays down a letter, the second player lays a letter beside it (at the back or front). Play continues like this. If a player forms a word, all tiles in that word are turned over to his colour. Words are built up crossword fashion.
When all the letters have been used, the winner is the player with the most of his colour in the crossword.

A road safety game to educate children about the Highway Code, whether they are walking or cycling.
'Kerb Drill Bill' gives the advice.

This is the rarest Pepys game, by a mile. Even the guru of Pepys data doesn't have a copy. We know it existed because there were adverts for it in the back of the rules of most card games in the 40's.

Mythic Migration is a 2 or 4 player, light strategy game. Players compete to be the first to get all their mythic creatures across the board.

The terrain is the obstacle. The board begins covered as plains (1 hex tile thickness) which no one can cross. During their turn players have two action points they can divide as they wish. They can move terrain hexes to build up (create mountains two tiles thick) for Yetis to cross, tear down (reveal the base board of water) for the Nessies to cross, or move their creatures towards safety (Yetis on mountains, and Nessies on water).

Beware, all your terrain movements potentially help your opponent(s), so minimizing the help you give them while maximizing their moves to your advantage is key!

Game Contents:
1 Full Color Rule Book
1 Wood Board (4 pieces)
4 Wooden Double-Sided Yeti Tokens
4 Wooden Double-Sided Nessie Tokens
28 Wooden Double-Sided Terrain Tiles

Music Maestro introduces your child to the sights and sounds of the orchestra. Play the audio cassette, Listen to the sounds of 32 Instruments in a narrated parade, Learn to match the sounds with the instrument names and pictures in a "Lotto" game.

Land Grab is an abstract played with a standard chess set. It was first published as part of Chief Herman's Next Big Thing.

The object is to, using your pieces, create a continuous line enclosing over half of the board, including your home row. Pieces move as in normal chess, although the king is the only piece which can capture. Pieces start off of the board and each turn a player can either place a piece on their home row or move one of their existing pieces. Which pieces can be placed is determined by the number of pieces of both colors already in that column.

As a Free Captain, adventurer, and member of the Society of Clockwork Engineers, you travel across the breadth of Arkady. Recently, you find yourself in the back room of Rasmuson's Bookshop in the heart of Easley by the River. There, on shelves heavy with dust, you find a leather bound volume and from between its pages a letter drops. Its author describes a fabled ancient brass clock and navigation device, the Antikythera, whose 6 parts were disassembled and hidden in the city of Val Justinia to prevent it from falling into the hands of a shadowy cabal operating within the S.C.E's very halls. The letter goes on to say that if the cabal and its allies, the Federation of Air Pirates, were to discover this device, they could wreak untold havoc, potentially circumnavigate the globe and attack Arkady’s eastern border.

At first you dismiss this letter as rumor and hoax but rumors have a way of sometimes becoming truth...

Clockwork Cabal is a game for one player lasting about 20 minutes. You win by locating all 6 parts of the Antikytheria before time runs out.

Required to play:
1 player pawn
1d12
13 small eurocubes
and the deck of 54 cards

there are 3 types of cards in the deck:

City Sector cards form the map of the city that you move across during the game. You build the city as you progress
Location cards list events that need to be resolved and let you find the parts of the Antikytheria
Player cards keep track of your health, knowledge, strength and items found.

item.description:
The king has died with no clear successor! The players—potential heirs all—are scrambling to put together their power bases by dispatching trusted agents and allies to garner support across the breadth of the kingdom. Nobody wants open warfare, but some conflict is sure to break out.

Fealty is a game of positioning and territory control. Each turn, all players add one piece to the game board, with increasing constraints on placement as time goes on. Some pieces have an effect when brought into play. At the end of the game, all pieces place influence in order of speed, claiming territory and blocking slower opposing pieces. The player who has maneuvered his or her pieces to place the most influence onto the board wins.

item.description:
Gear Jacket is a print-and-play combat-based game for two to four players. Each player takes on the role of a Gear Jacket pilot and battle his or her opponents in a variable arena.

In the not-too-distant future, a struggling television network gambled on the idea of a reality show about giant robots battling each other. The concept was a huge hit. Across the globe, young men and women dreamed of becoming Gear Jacket pilots and fighting for wealth and fame.

With Gear Jacket, you can take control of one of the famous Gear Jacket giant robots and take on one to three opponents!

There are twelve arena cards, each with six spots on which a player can land. Any number of these arena cards can be combined in any configuration to create the combat arena in which players will battle. Terrain tokens can be added to further diversify the arena.

There are twelve different Gear Jackets in the base game, with more planned for future expansions. Players select the Gear Jacket of their choice. Each player also takes five combat cards and a damage card. Each combat card represents a different section of the Gear Jacket--Head, Chest, Arms, etc. Combat is based on predicting the opponent's moves. The attacker selects two combat cards, while the defender chooses three. These cards are simultaneously revealed. Any cards revealed by the attacker that are not matched by the defender count as hits. Hits in different sections cause different amounts of damage, and may have extra penalties for the defender, as well.

There are also rules for game variants such as King of the Hill, Death Race 2000, and Tag that allow for further game diversity.

Description from the publisher:

Scofflaws are brawling in the streets of Deadwood. The railroad is being built, and to you and the other gangs in the badlands of South Dakota, this means one thing: cold, hard cash. As a cowboy on the wrong side of the law you know just how to take control of this shanty-town: threaten, fight, and kill off your rivals.

Deadwood is a wild-and-wooly board game with a quick and deadly twist on classic worker placement games. Your gang consists of three different classes of cowboys with different strengths: greenhorns, gunslingers, and trail bosses. Cowboys ride into town to gain control of (annex) buildings and fight other gangs' cowboys in shootouts.

At the beginning of the game, the town of Deadwood consists of the Town Hall, the Church, the Sheriff's Office, the Saloon, and four other randomly drawn buildings. Additional buildings are constructed whenever a cowboy annexes the Town Hall. Each building has at least one unique ability that is used immediately, with some buildings offering more long-term advantages.

A cowboy accesses these advantages by controlling the building. To gain control a player simply places one of his gang on a building tile, "annexing" it. Other gang leaders can try to gain control of your buildings through shootouts. The player that instigates the shootout receives a Wanted Poster token; the more cowboys you try to kill off, the more Wanted Poster tokens you collect, and the higher the fine you must pay at the end of the game.

Deadwood can end one of three ways: the Train Station is placed on the board once the railroad is built and completed, there are no more Wanted Poster tokens in the Crime Pool, or any player has no more cowboys alive. The player with the most cash at the end of the game is the winner!

item.description:
No sooner won, than ready to escape...

The cheeky Gelinis are not easy to get a hold of! You only barely manage to grab them before they are snatched away again. The winner is the player at the end of the game with the most Gelinis in his collection.

Contents...
45 Gelini cards
9 Gelini figures
Rule book.

In this game players attempt to catch as many of the nine Gelinis as they can. All the Gelinis (small plastic bears) start in the middle of the table. Each turn a player can play a coloured card to take to appropriate Gelini (bear)and put it in front of them. 
But watch out! Your opponents can steal your Gelinis from you. If he plays a card of the colour of Gelini you have he can take it from you, your only hope is to defend by playing yet another card of the same colour to stop him. Only good defense will help you win the game.

The Beautiful Game is a soccer replay game that simulates the highlights of a soccer match.

Each game played simulates goal chances of the teams during a match by using statistical team ratings and dice rolls. The player can play a single match, or with multiple games, simulate an entire league season. Many expansion sets of additional leagues and championships are available separately.

The basic game is simple and short (usually under 5 minutes), only determining if goals have been scored during the match by using the two teams' attack and defense ratings, chance cards, and a die rolls to see if a goal was scored. Additional rules add the ability to identify scoring players and the time of the goal, and noting injuries and suspensions of players.

From the publisher's site:
The Beautiful Game has been awarded the TABLETOP GAME OF THE DECADE by Jamie Marshall's 'Sports Digest'

The game includes the most current English Premier League teams available at time of printing

Watch a football match, live or on television, enjoy the action, the mid-field struggle,the joy of victory for your team, the despair of defeat, but a few hours after the final whistle what do you remember ? I suspect mainly the dramatic bits, the goals, the great saves, the near misses, the chances scorned. So that's exactly what you get in 'The Beautiful Game', those brief moments that decided the match, for better or worse, the bits that make up your memories, the talking points, the incidents that stay with you at least until next match day.

'The Beautiful Game' (henceforward 'BG') is an accurate replay game, accurate in results that is, and goal scorers, but unlike most soccer replay games it requires no user-decisions (which will appeal to some but not all) and is fast to play, just four to ten minutes per match, depending on how much you want to know in terms of stats.

For 'BG' is a layer game, three layers in this case, the basic quick-result is layer one, add on some personality with goal scorers, times of goals, that's layer two, and get involved in some simple book-keeping by recording (generic) bookings and injuries and rewarding winning form, plus adding some 'joining up' commentary, that's layer three. Even with all three layers most matches will take no more than 6-7 minutes, unless it's a real cracker !

The Kings Health is failing. You have a very small claim to the throne; if only your bloodline were just a little stronger! Always a bright child, you realize that history is written by the winner and it’s time to think like a winner. You’re going to rewrite a little history. The problem is that your opponents are trying to rewrite history as well. Can you create the strongest bloodline and become the ruler of the land?

Stratagy, Hand Management, Bluffing and a liberal dose of fun are all mixed into this game.
 140 cards
6 [You] cards in 6 colors
14 [wild] family tree cards (white)
120 family tree cards
 20 in each of 6 colors

Each set contains 
5 Great Grand Fathers (1 special)
5 Great Grand Mothers (1 special)
3 Grand Fathers (1 special)
3 Grand Mothers (1 special)
2 Fathers (1 special)
2 Mothers (1 special)
1 YOU card

Set up-
Take 1 set of cards for each player and the wild cards
Take the You cards for each of those sets and randomly distribute them to each player. This card is your color for this game. You will only score points for wild cards and your color played.
Shuffle all sets and the wild cards together and place them face down on the table where everyone can easily reach it.
Deal out 6 cards to each player
You are ready to begin.
On your Turn:
You may do only one of the following things on your turn.
 Play 1 card
 Draw 1 card
 Discard 3 cards and draw 2
 Swap an opponents played card with one from your hand
There is a hand limit of 7 cards. you may not have more that 7 cards in your hand at any time. (this included your YOU card.

You Start building your family Tree from your Great Grand Parents down to You. You must have played a Great Grand Father and a great Grand Mother next to each other (This creates a Mariage) in order to play a Grand Mother or Grand Father on that set. 
A complete family tree will consits of 4 married Great Grand Parents. The Second row will have 2 sets of Maried Grand Parents. The third row of course will have Your Mother and Father. Last but certainly not least is you, in the fourth and final row.

The game ends when one player places their YOU card. At this point the round continues till everyone has the same number of plays, and points are tallied.
The person with the most points in their family tree is the winner of the game and becomes the ruler of the land.

Keeping your color secret from the other players as long as possible is a key factor in winning the game. If plyers dont know what color you are they cannot steal a card from your family tree.

(from GMT webpage:)

Napoleonic 20 Multi-Pack, Volume I

Fading Glory is the second game (No Retreat - The Russian Front Deluxe Edition is the first) we (GMT Games) are producing as part of our strategic friendship/partnership with Victory Point Games, and the first game we are producing from their popular Napoleonic 20 series. The idea for this and future volumes is that we will take multiple existing games from the VPG Napeoleonic 20 series, add an as-yet-unpublished game to the mix, and create a GMT boxed game with 3-4 games in the box, using larger (3/4") counters and GMT production.

The Napoleonic 20 game system from Victory Point Games features lower-level wargame complexity on maps where, generally, 20 pieces or fewer are in play at one time (total, for both sides). This creates tense, dramatic and fast-playing situations on the board where higher echelon troop formations (generally corps) vie for position and dominance. Subscribers to C3i have recently enjoyed Jena 20, a game in this series which features eight pages of Standard rules and one-to-two pages of exclusive rules per title.
 Veteran game designer Joe Miranda, with developers Alan Emrich and Lance McMillan, have created and refined a highly popular game series that is growing all the time. (Based on Joe's series rules, Alan, Lance, and Steve Carey have each designed one of the games in this multi-pack - in addition to Joe's Waterloo game.) A hallmark feature is the use of narrative random event cards that help “tell the stories” unique to each battle and small campaign. This “friction of war” element, combined with the operational-level maneuvers, combat, and even lulls, provide players a fun exercise in the Napoleonic parry-and-thrust of grand battles as armies close to bayonet-point to see which will break first.

This edition includes the latest version (3.0) of the Standard series rules.
 Morale plays an vital role, as both sides can ‘spend’ this resource to force march their units, help rally stragglers, or commit reserves to a key attack or defense. But look out… when a side’s morale is reduced to zero, it has lost the game!

Included in this Multi-Pack are:


 Salamanca 20 (Wellington vs. Marmont, 1812)
 Smolensk 20 (Napoleon vs. Barclay de Tolly in the near-battle to decide the Russian Campaign, 1812)
 Borodino 20 (Napoleon vs. Kutusov before Moscow, 1812)
 Waterloo 20 (Napoleon vs. Blucher and Wellington, 1815) 


Game Components:


 Four 17” x 22” mounted maps (2 boards, backprinted)
 117 3/4" Counters (thick, with Rounded corners, like No Retreat)
 48 Event cards (12 for each game)
 One 8-page Standard Rules booklet
 4 Exclusive Rules sheets
 One Player’s Aid mat
 Two Player Aid charts
 2 six-sided Dice


DESIGN: Joe Miranda
DEVELOPER: Alan Emrich & Lance McMillan
ART DIRECTOR: Rodger B. MacGowan
COUNTER ART: Tim Allen & Richard Starke
MAP ART: Knut Grünitz

item.description:
Quble – A Twisting, Turning, Fun Word Game!

It's a cross between Boggle and a Rubik's Cube.

To play Quble, players have the option to twist and turn the cube to build words in 60-second rounds using letters worth varying point values (point values are indicated on each letter). The strategy is to search for the most or longest words and accumulate the highest score possible. Each player must decide how to best allocate their play time between moving the cube or searching and calling out each word with its point value. Typically, a game consists of 2 to 5 rounds of play. Players compete for the highest score by adding up the letter values for all words appearing anywhere around the cube. The letters can wrap around the sides of the cube from one face to another and must links diagonally, vertically, or horizontally. In QUBLE JUMBLE and FIRST TO FORTY, scoring may be based upon the length of the word. The more letters in a word, the more points.

Besides word game play, QUBLE can also be played as a conventional brain teaser by matching up each face of the puzzle by solid colors.

Rulebook includes 7 variants, mostly in the scoring and win conditions.

Two 4 x 7 sliding-tile games, with a letter and point value on each tile. The goal is to achieve a high score by forming interlocking words both horizontally and vertically. Two boards allows for both solo and competitive play.

item.description:
ãƒ´ã‚¡ãƒ³ã‚¬ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ (Vanguard) is a Japanese trading card game published by Bushiroad. It was created in collaboration between Akira ItÅ (Yu-Gi-Oh! R), Satoshi Nakamura (Duel Masters), and Bushiroad president Takaaki Kidani. The game was also released in conjunction with a TV anime series, "ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒˆ!! ãƒ´ã‚¡ãƒ³ã‚¬ãƒ¼ãƒ‰" (Cardfight!! Vanguard).

In the game, players "ride" a unit as their Vanguard, which represents them on the board. They may also summon other units as Rear Guards to attack or support. The game is won by doing 6 points of damage to the opponent's Vanguard.

As players attack, if they are using their vanguard they can "drive check" whereby they check the top card of their deck for "triggers" which increase power and have other effects, and add these cards to their hand. Triggers can also be revealed when players take damage to their vanguard by performing a "damage check".

At the start of the game, each player places their grade 0 starting vanguard face down in the "vanguard circle" and then draws 5 cards. They may return any number of cards to the deck and re-draw to form their starting hand, but only once. It's a good tactic to return trigger cards from your first hand as these are better utilised when drawn from the deck as part of a "drive check" or "damage check".

Once the players are done setting up their initial hand they determine who goes first (often, rock-paper-scissors is used for this) and then each turn follows the same turn order:

1. Stand up (only at the start of the game, and both players perform this action simultaneously whereby they flip over their vanguard)
2. Stand and Draw
3. Ride
4. Call
5. Attack
6. Guard
7. Drive Check
8. Damage Check
9. (more attacks? Go back to 5)
10. Turn end - change to other player and go back to 2

It's worth noting that strategically, taking damage early in the game can be beneficial as you can use cards in the damage zone to "counter blast" (flip the cards over to activate special actions on certain units).

item.description:
Kings & Queens Rummy is a variant on contract rummy in which each round consists of two separate hands and players must play certain combinations of sets and runs with each hand while working toward the bigger goal of playing all of one's cards first.

To set up a round, the 216 cards – four decks, plus eight wild cards – are shuffled and each player dealt two separate piles of eleven cards. Players swap piles, then choose one of the two piles they hold to serve as their Queen hand. On a turn, a player draws the top card of the deck or the top three cards on the discard pile, optionally plays sets and runs and plays off opponents, then discards one card. To open, a player must first play a set and run from the Queen hand of 3-7 cards. Once the player does this, she may meld additional cards and play off opponents.

Once a player has run out of cards in the Queen hand, she picks up the other pile – the King hand – and needs to play a set of 3-7 cards from this hand before being able to play off opponents once again. The round ends when a player runs out of cards in her King hand. The other players are penalized based on the value of cards remaining in hand, and the player with the lowest score after five rounds wins.

A double-box with two games. Happy Families was one but the other was a quiz card game, associated with Wilfred Pickles (1900-1978). Pickles was a noted radio performer for 30 years, starting in the 40's. He is pictured on the box.
The game has 29 cards. Each card has questions on them, and a score that can be earned if you answer correctly; 5 points (yellow), 10 points (red) or 20 points (blue).

36 cards featuring Popeye characters regularly seen in the TV version which started in 1961. Popeye is pictured on the box. The game play is simple. Each player gets a stack of cards. These remain face-down in front of him. The first player turns over the top card of his stack. If it is a character card, play passes to the next player. But if it is a Spinach card, the next player must 'Put' the nimber of cards indicated on the can of spinach (either 1, 2 or 3). If no more spinach is added whilst he is taking this action, all the cards played go to the player who played the spinach card and he puts them face-down under his stack.

This is a slightly altered variant of Old Maid or Donkey. 36 cards featuring characters from The Huckleberry Hound Show, such as the Hound himself, Mr. Jinks, Yogi Bear and Pixie & Dixie.
Players must collect pairs of the same card. Curiously, the company have included two 'Booby' cards and added the instruction 'one is spare and should be removed before dealing'.

Object of the game is to manipulate Your marbles into the scoring wheel and be the first player whose scoring wheel makes one complete revolution.

Each player places his marbles into the outside channel of his teeter board. A player's scoring wheel is the same color as his teeter board. 
At the word "GO" players work their teeter board in a teeter-totter motion manipulating their marbles up & down the teeter board and through the opening, attempting to manuever them into the scoring wheel. The first player whose scoring wheel makes one complete revolution wins the game.

"A relatively abstract game but still intensely exciting form of Motocross." - from the rules.
Players roll dice to create their rider by comparing each roll to the Preparation Chart. 5 rolls are needed per rider, giving him Basic Speed, Skill Rating, Block Ability, Control Rating and Stamina Factor. These five abilities are tested at different times during the race. It is a race game but has no board, laps are recorded on paper. The winner is the first rider to complete a set number of laps.
First published in Games Unlimited's Random fanzine.

A partnership card game, played with traditional playing cards.
Each player is dealt 13 cards but only 12 tricks are played for. The 13th card is used at the start to give to your partner. This should indicate how many tricks you think you can win. The card will be used later in the game. Tricks are won by playing 1, 2 or 3 cards. 1 card played is just a normal trick as in Bridge or Whist, but there are specific rules about what constitutes a trick playing 2 or 3 cards.
100 points equals a game. Before play begins, players decide on a 'best of' five, say, i.e. the first pair to score three games would be the winner.

Back To Iraq, 3rd Edition (B2I3e) is a "what if" simulation of the fighting that might occur across the northern littoral of the Persian Gulf if the US-led anti-terrorism Coalition decides on a ground war to finally settle with the Baghdad regime.

B2I3e is a two player wargame of low to intermediate complexity that posits this might-be war lasting about a month. We believe that is about the maximum time before the Coalition Ground force's diminishing supplies, coupled with a loss of the domestic political will necessary to continue the fighting, would bring about a settlement if victory were not achieved in the field.

(Form the introduction).

Major changes with the previous editions are the units, with new Order of Battle and factors. The units also are now mostly "two steppers". The combat table is also different at all, with separate combat tables for coalition and Militant Islamic.

Two scenarios, one against Iraq and Al Qaeda, and the second also against Iran and Iraq. Turkish and Syrian intervention is possible in both scenarios.

The Advanced rules cover Strategic targets, Airstrikes, Special Operations Forces, Command and Control and Additional Forces

Game Scale:
Turn: 2 days
Hex: 17 miles / 27.54 km
Unit: Brigade to Army

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (176 5/8" counters)
One 24 page rules booklet

In this game the players build a pyramid of glass marbles. Aim is to place the last marble on top of the pyramid.
Besides placing a new marble of his color on the board, a player can move one of his marbles already on the board by raising it one or two levels. Or a player can take back two marbles from the board by making a square using four of his own marbles.

This way a dynamic game is going on with a rising and shrinking pyramid.

Italian game. The scope of the game is that one of guess the titles them of two films and to prepare a cinematographic troupe composed of 8 members.

The mechanism of the game is question and answer: if the answer is exact the player advances the number of spaces indicated on the cad, and will play out the event on the back of the card; if incorrect, the player moves back two spaces and is affected by the text on the space.

2340 questions in 12 categories.

If you pull out a pair of pants you'll lose one turn until you can try for silly socks again. The first player to collect three matching pairs wins. For 2 to 4 players, ages 3 to 5.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Greed, Pride, Gluttony, Wrath, Luxury, Idleness, and Envy – the infamous "Seven Deadly Sins". For the faithful, they instill horror. For you, on the other hand, they present a wonderful business opportunity!

In The Road to Canterbury, you play a medieval pardoner who sells certificates delivering sinners from the eternal penalties brought on by these Seven Deadly Sins. You make your money by peddling these counterfeit pardons to Pilgrims traveling the road to Canterbury. Perhaps you can persuade the Knight that his pride must be forgiven? Surely the Friar's greed will net you a few coins? The Miller's wrath and the Monk's gluttony are on full public display and demand pardoning! The Wife of Bath regales herself in luxury, the Man-of-Law languishes in idleness, and that Prioress has envy written all over her broad forehead. And the naughty stories these Pilgrims tell each other are so full of iniquity they would make a barkeep blush! Pardoning such wickedness should be easy money, right?

Not quite. For you to succeed as a pardoner, you'll need to do more than just sell forged pardons for quick cash. To keep your services in demand, you will actually need to lead these Pilgrims into temptation yourself! Perhaps some phony relics might help? There is also one big catch. The Seven Deadly Sins live up to their name: each sin that a Pilgrim commits brings Death one step nearer, and a dead Pilgrim pays no pardoners!

So much to forgive, so little time. Will you be able to outwit your opponents by pardoning more of these Pilgrims' sins before they die or finish their pilgrimage to Canterbury?

item.description:
This is a book game. Published as a book it includes multiple black & white and color maps. There are 3 games described, the Red, the Green and the Black game.

The Black game is a solo effort to see how long it takes and how accurate you can be with determining your map pinpoints.

The Red game is meant for 4 players or fewer. It is a game of chance and is won by the first person to reach the bombing target (the German city of Coblenz).

The Green game is for any number of players, again as a game of chance but requires finding Pinpoints via Latitude and Longitude.

In the Red and Green games a number of aircraft set off from their base in Kent to bomb a target at Coblenz.

The games requires the player to copy and create miniature airplanes, Compass Rose, 10 deg angle indicator and Latitude/Longitude Finder.

The game includes maps as well as extensive briefing triggered by either a draw from a deck of cards or dice roll. The players continue to roll/draw cards until they land on the target by exact count. Any overshooting requires the bomber to fly back around.

A briefing can have extensive instructions causing the player to head off track or be attacked by enemy fighters ending in a change of course and position on the map.

Sky Castles is a tile and worker placement game where the players collect gemstones from castles in the clouds. The theme is aimed at children, but the game claims to provide scope for strategic play at all levels.

The tiles depict a cloudscape dotted with gemstones. Each turn the player selects one of four face-up tiles and places it into the cloudscape so that the borders match adjacent tiles, and can optionally place a sprite token to claim a cloud or section of sky. There are three scoring rounds where the players score points for the gemstones that their sprites have claimed.

The gameplay is similar to other tile placement games (e.g. Carcassonne) but Sky Castles has less complexity and claims to be suitable for a younger audience while retaining similar strategic options.

In this game, two spacecraft armies fight each other as they try to reach the earth first and conquer it.

Each army is composed by 6 combat modules, each one representing one of the signs of the zodiac, and a mothership. The motherships are able to shoot "disc missiles" but only only can move laterally along the gameboard's central circle, while the combat modules can move forward and feature an spring-based system that makes them "explode" in case one disc missile hits it's front.

At the start of the game, each combat module is placed over it's correspondent sign in the circle, and the motherships are placed in each side of the gameboard. The starting player moves one of his modules one square forward and then shoots his mothership. If he hits and destroys one of the other player's modules, he can advance one of his again, until he fails, ending his turn. The first to move one of his modules over the central square (The earth) wins the game.

Aim! Throw! Claim a square! Or knock your opponent out of there!

The classic 2-player skill game Tic Tac Toe just got more action-packed with Tic Tac Throw! Players must throw the cubes with "x" and "o" on the vinyl board in right places to form the row.
Try to be the first to get Tic Tac Toe!

Starmada: Fleet Ops is a "fleet-scale" game using the same database as Starmada: Admiralty Edition science-fiction starship combat game. S:FO is very similar to S:AE in many respects, but Starmada: Fleet Ops' flow is intended to be faster-moving and more abstracted.

Game scale is "grand tactical", each ship is a single counter on the map, and its statistics (damage level, weapons, and so on) are tracked individually, although not in as much detail as Starmada: Admiralty Edition. (Any ship you can build using Admiralty Edition's ship design rules can be represented in Starmada: Fleet Ops, making the two games highly compatible).Construction rules are included, and also guidelines on converting Admiralty Edition ships to Fleet Ops statistics. An entire fleet of ships can be represented on a single standard sheet of paper.

Play is simultaneous. Each player takes turns giving orders to his units by placing a marker on top of one ship to indicate the orders it has been given. Once all ships have orders, initiative is determined. The player losing initiative moves all his ships first (giving the non-moving player an advantage), but then fires first in the subsequent fire phase (gaining an advantage).

Movement and firing are both simplified and sped up from Admiralty Edition, reducing the amount of record keeping and the number of die rolls. Mechanics new to the Starmada system are introduced, including morale and command ships.

The product is available as either a download in Adobe .pdf format, or as a print-on-demand saddle-stitched book (44 pages). Additional material, including printable colour counters and map sheets, is available for free download from Majestic 12 Games' website for purchasers of either format.

Socker is a two player breakthrough abstract board game that simulates a soccer or rugby-like game where socking opposing pieces is a means to the end zone.

Socker is played on a 9x11 field, 9 columns and 11 rows. Each player has five man tokens (for example meeples), called sockers, and there is a ball token.

To set up the game, the ball is placed in the center space of the board. Players toss a coin to see who plays first. Starting with the toss winner, each player places all his or her sockers upright on any empty spaces that are in their nearest half of the field, but not adjacent (vertically, horizontally or diagonally) to the ball and not in the center row.

Players continue alternating turns and do the following.

On a turn, a player must perform one to three actions listed below using any of his or her upright (referred to as active) sockers.

 Move. An active socker may be moved to any adjacent empty space. This includes the goal and out of bounds areas. However, at the end of a player’s turn, no more that three of his or her sockers may be in the goal and out of bounds regions.
 Kick. If an active socker is adjacent to the ball, the ball may be kicked directly away one space provided the destination space is empty.

Sock. If an active socker is adjacent to an opponent’s socker, then the opponent’s socker may be pushed directly away one space provided the destination space is empty. The pushed socker is then put on its side to indicate that it is inactive and will not be able to perform any actions for one turn.

Any action or active socker may be used multiple times. Player may use any combination of actions and active sockers, and in any order they like.

When a player completes his or her actions all that player’s inactive sockers are put upright and become active again. This ends the player’s turn.

The goal of the game is to kick the ball over your goal line, into your farthest 1x9 row. Players can choose either of the following winning conditions: first to score a set number of goals (usually one), or most goals after a set number of turns followed by sudden death if necessary. After a goal, players should use the setup procedures with the non-scoring player going first. For sudden death, only two sockers per player are used, and a coin toss is used to determine who plays first.

Special Rules

Out of Bounds: The first and last columns of the playing field excluding the goal spaces are out of bounds. If the ball is pushed out of bounds, the ball is immediately moved to the center space of the same row. If the center space is occupied, the owner of the occupying socker can choose any empty space adjacent to the center space.

Repeat Positions: When a position is repeated, the player that plays next gets one extra action (total of four instead of three) to break the deadlock.

Static Positions: The maximum number of sockers on the edge is three. This prevents unmovable defensive positions behind the goal line or along the sides of the board. That is, positions where the offensive player can not push the ball or an opponent's socker.

name.value: Mage Knight: Il Gioco Da Tavolo

item.description:
The Mage Knight board game puts you in control of one of four powerful Mage Knights as you explore (and conquer) a corner of the Mage Knight universe under the control of the Atlantean Empire. Build your army, fill your deck with powerful spells and actions, explore caves and dungeons, and eventually conquer powerful cities controlled by this once-great faction! In competitive scenarios, opposing players may be powerful allies, but only one will be able to claim the land as their own. In cooperative scenarios, the players win or lose as a group. Solo rules are also included.

Combining elements of RPGs, deck-building, and traditional board games the Mage Knight board game captures the rich history of the Mage Knight universe in a self-contained gaming experience.

item.description: This is a very simple, turn-based, game, aimed mainly at kids. The objetive is to score the more points possible, using little rackets to throw some badminton-like plastic cones into a score field. The one who get the most points, wins.

A devilish print-and-play game of temporal competition, where two time travellers compete to complete four objectives by travelling back in time to alter four separate time-lines, and interfere with each other's plans.

To play the game, you will need :
- 1 A4 printout of the board (see files or images section)
- 4 red counters
- 4 blue counters
- 10 black counters
- 1 D6

Rules are printed on the board, and transcribed here :

Place player pieces on the beginning of any timeline (I - IV, coloured), and a marker on the beginning of the clock track (X).

At the beginning of each round, advance the clock marker one hour.
If the end of the clock track is reached by the first clock marker, add a second at X, and continue advancing this, so that 24 hours are played.
When the second clock marker reaches the end of its track, the game ends.

The player with the greatest number of achievements (A or B) wins.
If more than one player is tied for the greatest number of achievements, the player with the least pieces wins.
If more than one player shares the lowest number of pieces, the player whose oldest piece has advanced the farthest through time wins.

In turn, move your earliest piece (that nearest to X along the time-lines I - IV) forward one space, or roll 1D6.
 On a roll of 6, you may move any piece on the board (with the exception of achievements) one space in any direction along its time-line.
 On any other roll, place a new piece on any time-line, that number of spaces back in time from your earliest piece, counting from the previous space.
 If the new piece is placed beyond the starting space, it is lost in time, and your turn ends.

If you land level with another of your pieces, remove the older of the two pieces, and collect the achievement associated with its time-line if you have not already.
If you land on the same space as another piece, move that piece to the equivalent time on any other time-line.

For a co-op game, use only one clock counter (12 hours), and ignore one of the scoring tracks.
