item.description:
A card game that is similar to the traditional playing card game of Racing Demon. One player is the Bookmaker and offers odds on each of the horses in any one race.
For the race, cards are turned over and the horse named advances along the 'course'. And there are wild cards that affect the race; Jockey Falls, Little Brown Dog, Whip, and Spur.
There is no skill at all apart from betting wisely or, if you are the Bookmaker, offering the right odds so that you can make a profit

This game is composed of eighteen wooden chips (pawns) in two colors (nine for each player) and a board with seventy-seven cells, of which eighteen are marked with two different colors.

Each player place his pawns in their respective colour cells and the game begins. Players move their pawns alternately one by one. The movement is one square forward or sideways, but never diagonally or backward. It’s forbidden not move a pawn in the player's turn.

When a player, after moving a pawn, trap a chip of the other player between two of his own, that chip is removed. Only one chip can be removed in each turn.

The game ends when no piece can be moved forward, being all in the last cell. The player who gets the most pawns to the last row of the board, opposite to the area in which he started, wins the game.

This game is part of the rare "Club series" from NAC, a company more known for his wargames than for this kind of abstract games. The other known titles from this series are: The Backbone, Manhattan and Daiquiri

This title covers two different games:
- a classical battleship-like game, which, by using tracking system by means of polar co-ordinates, is more modern than former types;
- a "battle of missiles", new game in which success depends mainly on deduction and method.

Both games require different printed forms, but are provided with the same support for two Radar screens: the first one is used to "emit" missiles and to track firing against the enemy, the second one to place ships or missiles and to "receive" enemy firing.

4 spinning tops for 4 different games, that's essentially Tifon (Typhoon) 4.

Although other elements like marbles or a shooting platform are included, the metal spinnings tops, identified as "spaceships" in the gamer's manual, are the main element in the different games described:

-Cosmic Soccer: The marbles are placed in the center of the field and, then, a special spinning top is released on it, throwing the marbles into the different scored goals on each side of the field. The player with the most points, wins.

-Starship stop: A spinning top it's thrown into a flat surface and the players try to "catch" it with the shooting platform and its magnetic projectile. 10 points are given to the one who catch the top and 5 to the one who just knock it down.

-Competition: The players spin their tops and the one with the top that falls last, wins.

-Fight: The four tops are thrown into the field and crash against each other. The player with the last top standing, wins.

The manual encourages the players to create it's own games and variations, and suggest some possibilities.

In Imperial General, the armies are equal, the odds are equal, the strengths are equal, the difference is you!
 In Imperial General both sides have identical decks and start in identical setups. Then, each turn, the players select what their next formation change, or order, will be for the next turn. The changes are compared and a matrix on the bottom of each card shows how may points your opponent loses.
 Rounds continue until one side has lost an entire company. THen the game ends and the side with the most points (men) remaining-wins.
 Imperial General is part of the Warcoach Games "10 Minute War Game" series.

Players move around the board to complete with all "Senators" and 48 state questions (which is the amount of states in the USA at the time). They have to collect enough cards and answer "special" question to become President and win the game.

When backgammon became a fad in the early seventies, the game went from that thing on the back of inexpensive checker boards to the gambling rage of the jet set.

This solitaire game was created to cash in on the craze. Sixty pre-programmed games have been divided into four courses of fifteen games. Place one of the games into the tray. Using the slides in the frame of the tray, the player only sees one move at a time. After sizing up any given situation, the player advances a slide to see what backgammon champion Tim Holland would have done.

The game contains the tray, a really cheap backgammon set, thirty two game cards and rules.

The gameboard is a nineteen-by-nineteen grid with the corners missing; the first and last rows and columns are elongated. In this elongated spaces, players may place more than one letter to make their words.

From a pool of letters, the players determine which letters will be randomly added to their hands. The players, in turn, add their letters to the grid to make words in crossword fashion.

The game contains one sheet or rules and nineteen games printed in ten sheets of paper. The game is consistent with Robert Mansfield’s packaging that allows a complete set to be stuffed into a standard business envelope.

The PRIMARY OBJECTIVE: 
"Finish them! Before they finish you!"

Gain the reign of the nefarious organized underground.

Rollers (players) will gamble and make deals, purchase and flip (sell) from the various high-end illicit contraband markets (on domestic soil/US & foreign lands).

This is a roll-and-move game. Rollers roll the dice and move their game piece throughout The KINGPIN! Game world's cities, states and countries. As rollers travel The KINGPIN! Game world they are allowed to buy or sell available products, pick a PUSH YOUR LUCK card (like "chance" or "community chest") which gives rollers a 50/50 chance of getting or losing monies. Rollers can also gamble in "La$ Vega$", "3Card MONT3 CARLO", or "AC", for their chance at the 7 / 11 jackpot roll. Rollers must increase their wealth and their worth while eliminating all street competition.

Rollers can hire one of The KINGPIN! Game's paid "KILLA$" to attempt to assassinate other rollers in The KINGPIN! Game, done by paying for hire - The KINGPIN! "KILLA$" (hit-men/assassins). The KINGPIN! "KILLA$" are hired killers in The KINGPIN! Game that operate for various fees/costs {$75,000 - $1M}.

The goal of The KINGPIN! Game is to be the last one standing! The solo survivor ~ the realized vision of the primary objective...

The KINGPIN!

The KINGPIN! Game comes with: 
The Official The KINGPIN! game rule book and soundtrack 
(hard copy of the rule book and CD with rules set to KINGPIN! MU$IK as well as a The KINGPIN! Game related score/sound Track) on one CD

EIC League is a tactical combat / RPG crossover that is completely customizable. You add your own dice and playing field to the EIC League rules that you download, and you are ready to go.

Every player is assigned the same number of credits (a budget) that they have to spend to buy and customize their units.

Players design units (either bipeds or tanks), equip them with the 7 ratings they need (body material, attack, defense, power, speed, detection & ECM), then outfit them with weapons, shielding, and special movements. After the units are completed, they pit their team against one or more opponents. The game is like chess on steroids!

The infinite combinations of weapons, movements and defenses against the other team's weapons movements and defenses makes for a unique playing experience each and every game.

Unit design can take up to 2 hours for first time players, and play time can range anywhere from 30 minutes to 4 hours. The object of the game is to obliterate the opposition and collect credits for rewards. With those credits, you can buy more units or upgrade your existing units through the roof.

Strategy is the key to winning. Do you use a bunch of fast and light units or just work with a couple of super strong slow units, or go with a mix of everything? Depending on what you do and what each opponent does, you can battle for hours or you can make a fatal mistake and have things end very quickly. No two games are alike!

name.value: Legend of the Galactic Heroes: My Conquest is a Sea of Stars

item.description:
Based off of the cult classic series of science fiction novels, Legend of the Galactic heroes tells the story of two empires in space, fighting a war for total control. On one side, the Free Planets Alliance, a corrupt democracy lead by a charismatic fraud, and on the other side, The Empire, a Benevolent Monarchy, lead by the Imperial Kaiser.

Legend of the Galactic Heroes: My Conquest is a Sea of Stars. puts you in command of one of these nations, on the eve of war, will you come out victorious, or will the underhanded dealings of your neighbor with the neutral world of Phezzan put you at a loss.

Game play is based around two boards, one is the strategic board where you command all the resources of your nation, and the other is the tactical board, where you can fight out the battles between massive fleets, numbering in the thousands.

Complexity - Moderate, only slightly more complex then a game of Axis and Allies.

Length - In Excess of Ten hours for a full game, individual battles take up to thirty minutes or so.

Suitability for Solitaire Play - Moderate, some elements of the game revolve around hidden units, but the rules for that are easily removed.

You are driving through the city of Lapalisse and try to collect two items and find one truth. When you get your items and truth, you rush out from the city. First one who leaves wins the game.
You move your car by pushing new tiles to the Nationale 7. When your car is in the right place you park and collect an item or leave Nationale 7 and turn to side roads in Lapalisse. You collect or lose the truth by driving to a "truth" tile.

From the designer of Glen More comes a new title published by Queen Games: Lancaster.

In 1413, the new king of England, Henry V of Lancaster, has ambitious plans: The unification of England and the conquest of the French crown! Each player takes the role of an ambitious aristocratic family. Who will be the best supporter of this young king, and the most powerful Lord of his time?

In Lancaster, the players want to proceed from simply being a Lord to being the most powerful ally of the king. They may achieve this by developing their own knighthood, as well as by clever deployment of individual knights in the counties of England, at their own castle, and to conflicts with France. In parliament, they try to push laws from which they will benefit themselves most. The player with the most power points at the end of the game is the winner.

Every turn, players send their knights to the different locations:
• Counties, where they compete with knights from other players for rewards and the favor of the nobles.
• The castle, to receive income or new knights.
• Into conflict with France, where all players combine their power and try to gain power points.

In the counties, the strength of the knights is important, as you can remove the knight of another player by placing a knight of your own with higher strength in the same location.

item.description:
Goal: Be the first, who visits all 12 lettered points (A-M) avoiding major mistakes

1 Preparing the map first you have to cut trees, buildings, a bridge and glue/insert these into the
 board, place policemen... 
2 Follow the streets/roads in recommended directions by rolling the die
3 Stop at lettered places (and policemen)
4 Explain the traffic signs you pass by; various mistakes will lead to penalties

Goal: Be the first to travel with 'Lufthansa GDR' from Berlin via Praha to Budapest

1. Choose your coloured plastic plane and roll the die by turns - you may start with a '6' at once, otherwise follow a circuit - Kicking your teammate(s) is not allowed
2. Follow instructions if you land on a marked area
3. Stopover in Praha

This game is situated in the low countries during the revolt against Spain, resulting in the independency of the Dutch Republic.
One player takes the Spanish side and the other the Dutch. Control of the land is achieved by controlling the various cities. To signify the control each city is covered with a chit which has a Spanish side and a Dutch side. 
At the beginning of the game the players decide on the number of rounds they will play (about 10 rounds per hour can be played, 20 to 30 round are recommended) and a die is rolled for each city. On a roll of 1, 2 or 3 the Spanish side is up, on 4, 5 or 6 the Dutch side. Each player gets three leaders to control their armies and 15 units of infantry. The Spanish get an extra two units of cavalry and the Dutch two units of naval troops (watergeuzen)
Each round both players roll a die. Their separate scores are the number of action points they have for that round. The combined number of both dies is used to decide on a random effect to be carried out before the round is started. 
Victory points can only be scored as the result of a specific random effect. For each province (there are 16 provinces with 1 to 8 cities) where one players controls all cities that player scores a victory point for each city in the province. 
The player with the highest roll starts the round, in case of a tie the Spanish player. Units are moved over the board by leaders, they cannot move alone. The naval units can move independently but only from one coastal city to another. Movement costs actions. A player can conquer cities by spending action points storming, starving or tricking them. A random event can cause the city to change its alliance at the start of a new round as well.
Battles between armies are a special affair: both sides take only one turn rolling dies, one die for a unit of infantry, three for cavalry and three for each point their best leaders ability is higher than the other players best leaders. First the defending player rolls the dies, scoring a hit for each 6 rolled. Then, after taking her losses, the attacker does the same, the defender taking her losses. The winner of the battle is the player who rolled the most sixes or, when both rolled the same number, the defender. The defeated player loses the entire army, both units and leaders!
After the last round there is a final victory point calculation. In this calculation a point is awarded for each city the player controls, regardless of province control.
